item.title: Bandits (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC #Faction

#GOC #Faction
Infobox

Bandits are the Zone’s opportunists, predators who thrive on chaos. Unlike Duty (GOC) or Freedom (GOC), they don’t care about ideology, the Zone, or science; only profit, survival, and intimidation. They operate in scattered groups, small gangs, and sometimes loose networks, rarely staying in one place for long.
Their camps are crude but defensible: abandoned buildings, overturned vehicles, or hastily dug trenches. Fires are common at night, and watchpoints are posted wherever they expect trouble. Bandits rely on stealth, ambushes, and traps; Most'll kill to rob, and rob to live another day.
There are a number of other bandits who prefer the more 'high class' robbery. Gaining profit from Smuggling and Black Markets more than pure looting. Although even with these kinds, be careful what you bring, they may just rob you anyway.
Doctrine: There is no code but self-interest. They respect strength and fearlessness, and punish weakness without hesitation. Survival and gain come first. Loyalty exists only within the gang, and even then it’s fleeting.
Relations:

Hostile to everyone outside their own, especially loners carrying gear. May attempt to kill you, but with certain individuals you can talk your way out.

Regular skirmishes with Duty (GOC) patrols, Freedom (GOC) bands and Clear Sky (GOC) Expeditions.

Sometimes cooperate with other criminals or desperate stalkers if there’s coin or equipment to be had.

Trade: Bandits deal in what they take — weapons, ammunition, stolen artifacts, rations, and information. Prices are high, trust is low, and double-crosses are frequent. Rarely trade for research or anomalies; their interest is immediate gain.
Advice: Avoid them when possible. If confronted, comply, retreat, or fight only if you have the advantage. Bandits are unpredictable, often armed, and willing to kill without warning. If you plan to trade, make sure it’s in a controlled environment, with escape routes memorized.
— The Guide

item.title: Clear Sky (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC #Faction

#GOC #Faction
Infobox

Clear Sky are the scholars-warriors of the Zone; stalkers who believe in understanding it rather than controlling it or worshipping it. They seek knowledge of anomalies, artifacts, and the Zone’s hidden rules, often putting themselves directly in harm’s way to study what others fear.
They are organized, disciplined, and heavily equipped, though not to the level of Duty (GOC). They move in small teams, often supported by field laboratories and portable scanners, mapping anomaly clusters and recovering samples. Their camps are tidy, with equipment meticulously maintained.
Doctrine: Knowledge above all. Clear Sky aims to study the Zone scientifically, cataloguing everything from minor anomalies to mutant behaviour. They avoid needless confrontation, but will fight if protecting their research or resources.
Relations:

Generally neutral to most factions, though clashes occur with Bandits (GOC) within the Swamp

Respect loners who demonstrate skill and caution, sometimes recruiting them as scouts or field assistants.

Trade: Unknown
Advice: Approach Clear Sky with respect for knowledge. They value competence, careful observation, and preparation. If you provide data, samples, or rare finds, you’ll be well-compensated and remembered favorably.
— The Guide

item.title: Duty (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC #Faction

#GOC #Faction
Infobox

Duty are soldiers in all but name. A paramilitary order that formed out of ex-military and survivors after the first incursions into the Zone. Their philosophy is simple and iron-bound: the Zone is a threat to mankind, and it must be contained or destroyed.
They’re disciplined, armed better than most, and usually set up in fortified bases; Rostok (GOC) is their stronghold. Expect sentries, patrols, and a chain of command that feels more like an army unit than a loose gang of stalkers. They recruit those who believe in order and in fighting the mutants head-on.
Doctrine: strict, militaristic, no patience for anarchists or dreamers. They see themselves as humanity’s shield, and treat anyone sympathetic to the Zone’s mysteries as dangerous.
Relations:

Bitter enemies with Freedom (GOC); where Duty preaches discipline, Freedom preaches liberty. The two clash whenever their patrols cross.
NOTE
Current Cease to Hostilities while Monolith (GOC) are a immediate threat.
Trade openly with Ecologists (GOC) for research samples, though with suspicion.

Tolerate loners so long as they don’t stir trouble in their territory.

Trade: Duty buys mutant parts and artifacts, but more for containment and study than curiosity. They pay fair, but they’ll log your name, your goods, and maybe your face. Once you trade with Duty, they remember you.
Advice: Respect their checkpoints. Don’t mouth off about “the beauty of the Zone”; it won’t endear you to them. If you want discipline, comradeship, and purpose, you may find a home with Duty. If you want freedom, you’ll find yourself at their gunpoint sooner or later.
— The Guide

item.title: Ecologists (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC #Faction

#GOC #Faction
Infobox

The Ecologists are not soldiers, though many wear suits thicker than a trooper’s armour. They are scientists; men and women of theory, sent here by institutes and governments that still cling to order outside the Zone. Their purpose is study: of anomalies, of mutations, of radiation, of whatever secrets this cursed land holds.
They keep their camps clean, their notes orderly, their eyes fixed on data. You’ll find them near anomaly fields or in research bunkers, always measuring, always observing. Some say they’re naïve; that numbers on a chart can’t capture the Zone. Others say they’re the only ones who might ever make sense of this madness.
Doctrine: Knowledge first. Containment, safety, and understanding before profit. They believe that by cataloguing and dissecting the Zone’s horrors, mankind can survive what comes next.
Relations:

Neutral to most. Their value is information, not blood.

They hire Loners and mercenaries alike for fieldwork, escorts, and sample collection.

Disliked by some factions, particularly those who see their research as exploitation or theft.

Trade: The Ecologists don’t barter in bullets or vodka. Their coin is research and artifacts. Bring them clean samples, fresh mutant organs, or stable artifacts, and they will reward you with rations, medicines, rare equipment, or even specialized protective suits. They trade in knowledge too; maps of anomaly clusters, warnings of mutant migrations, sometimes even insight into what keeps a man alive out here. Of course, the best rewards often go to those willing to risk their lives recovering the rarest pieces of the Zone.
Advice: Deal with them carefully. Their prices are fair, but their curiosity can be dangerous. They’ll ask you to fetch what most stalkers fear to touch. Yet if you can stomach the work, no one in the Zone pays better for truth in your hands.
— The Guide

item.title: Freedom (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC #Faction

#GOC #Faction
Infobox

Freedom are the wild ones, the opposite of Duty (GOC)’s discipline. They see the Zone not as a curse, but as a gift. To them, this place is a frontier of possibility; where nature, anomaly, and man collide in ways worth studying, even embracing.
They’re looser in structure than Duty (GOC). No strict ranks, no barking officers, more of a collective than an army. Their camps feel more like gatherings of friends than barracks, though don’t mistake that for weakness. Freedom fighters are skilled, and they know the land. They’ll fight tooth and nail if pressed.
Doctrine: The Zone belongs to everyone. They oppose restrictions, lockdowns, and containment. They believe knowledge should be shared freely, not locked behind steel doors. Some whisper that Freedom secretly worship the Zone, though most simply respect it.
Relations:

Enemies of Duty (GOC) — oil and water, they clash on sight. One sees the Zone as a disease, the other as a treasure.
NOTE
Current Cease to Hostilities while Monolith (GOC) are a immediate threat.
Friendly with Ecologists (GOC) when research is open and shared.

Generally tolerant of loners, drifters, and wanderers. If you’re not shooting at them, they’ll likely share a fire.

Trade: Freedom’s markets run a different sort of barter. They’re known to traffic in Western weapons; pistols, rifles, and the odd NATO surplus, moved through shadow routes and traded for favours or information.
More than that, they deal heavily in drugs: stimulants and sedatives for long patrols, experimental compounds for those who want to push the Zone’s edges, and narcotics that keep men quiet when silence is needed.
Prices swing with supply and risk; sometimes you get a good trade, sometimes you pay with a debt you can’t see coming.
Advice: Freedom are easier company than Duty (GOC), but don’t mistake their laid-back manner for carelessness. They’re serious about their cause and will defend it fiercely. If you trade with them, you’re dealing with people who see the Zone as sacred ground. Respect that, or they’ll make sure you leave their territory feet-first.
— The Guide

item.title: Monolith (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC #Faction

#GOC #Faction
Infobox

The Monolith are not like the others. They are zealots, fanatics bound by some unseen will. No one outside their circle knows the whole truth of what drives them, but all agree on this: they guard the heart of the Zone with suicidal devotion.
Their camps are silent, their patrols relentless. Men who once were stalkers, mercenaries, even soldiers vanish into the north, only to return as Monolith; their eyes glassy, their words filled with prayers to some "holy light." They fight with discipline and precision, but there is madness in their courage. They do not fear death, for they believe they are serving something greater than themselves.
Doctrine: Absolute faith in the Monolith. The Zone is sacred, and they are its chosen defenders. They seek to cleanse it of all who would trespass, especially those who pursue artifacts or knowledge not meant for mortal hands.
Relations:

Enemies to all outsiders, without exception. Barkeep (GOC), Duty (GOC), Freedom (GOC), Ecologists (GOC); none are spared.

Some believe they are controlled by something deeper in the Zone, though no proof has ever reached the outside world. The so called "Wish Granter"

Few who infiltrate their ranks ever return to speak of it.

Trade: The Monolith do not trade. They take, and they kill. Their “treasures”; weapons, artifacts, rations, are only gained by looting their corpses or raiding their strongholds. It is said they possess stockpiles of advanced arms and artifacts of terrible power, but prying them loose usually costs more lives than they’re worth.
Advice: Avoid them when you can, fight them when you must. They are not men anymore; at least, not in any sense that matters. Remember that bullets alone may not stop them; faith gives them strength, and in the Zone, sometimes faith is deadlier than radiation.
— The Guide

item.title: 20250824.1 - Anomaly Detected
item.description:
#GOC #JournalGOC

#GOC #JournalGOC


On the road up from Rookie, past Depot and short of Rostok (GOC), a contamination of radioactive material, possibly left over by anomaly

Location: Northern stretch of the road from Rookie Village (GOC), between the old Depot (GOC)and the outskirts of Rostok (GOC).
Came across a contamination zone along the road; constant low level radiation, enough to trigger the dosimeter's low-range chirp. The hotspot isn't natural, not in the geologic sense. More likely, a remnant of an anomaly that either burned out or shifted elsewhere, leaving behind its residue.
The pattern is close together, uniform. Soil and debris in a meter radius show elevated readings. Melted asphalt, I’ve seen this before. Looks like a Fruit Punch anomaly might’ve nested here once. Maybe during the last blowout or so.
No visible emissions now, but I wouldn't linger here too long, not to mention the Flesh and Izlom's . My boots clicked over bone fragments; likely scavengers or desperate rookies. Whatever this place did, it did it fast.
I marked the spot with hazard mark on my map and scratched a warning into the roadside barrier. It’s not worth losing a foot over a shortcut to Rostok (GOC).
Recommendation: Not dangerous but a detour through the trees eastward for now to avoid the mutants. And remind the rookies ;just because the anomaly’s gone, doesn’t mean its teeth ain’t still in the dirt.
The Guide

item.title: Burner
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

The Burner is one of the more straightforward but deadly anomalies out here. At first glance, it appears as a patch of scorched earth, blackened soil, or faintly glowing metal fragments. Get too close, and it releases sudden bursts of intense heat; flames, sparks, or scalding air that can sear skin and melt equipment.
Behavior: Mostly stationary but highly reactive. Movement in its vicinity triggers bursts; some specimens pulse rhythmically, others strike at random. Flames may rise from the ground, flare from nearby debris, or even follow heat signatures. Prolonged exposure causes serious burns, respiratory distress, and sometimes ignition of clothing.
Detection: Visual cues are key; charred earth, flickering heat waves, occasional smoke. Thermals are useful but unreliable; some Burners hide in otherwise cool patches, only revealing themselves when provoked.
Trade/Use: Ecologists occasionally take small residue samples or trace materials for study. Fire-hardened fragments are occasionally collected for crafting, though the risks usually outweigh the reward. Stalkers avoid transporting them unless absolutely necessary.
Advice: Keep distance. Don’t carry flammable materials nearby. Move carefully, and if you must pass through, cover exposed skin and eyes. The Zone does not forgive those who mistake fire for warmth.
— The Guide



Rostok (GOC) Burner Tunnel. West of City & in Wild Territory (GOC)

item.title: Electra
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.

The Electra anomaly is one of the more violent surprises the Zone throws at a man. It manifests as a series of faintly shimmering arcs of electricity, dancing across the ground or between metal objects. At a distance, it looks almost like lightning frozen mid-strike; beautiful, but deadly.
Behaviour: unpredictable and highly sensitive. Movement nearby can trigger sudden discharges, and even the slightest vibration may cause arcs to leap several meters. Not lethal in a single contact if you’re wearing proper gear, but repeated exposure quickly incapacitates. Electrical burns, cardiac arrhythmia, and muscular paralysis are common in unprepared stalkers.
Detection: glow and faint hum are the primary signs. Often paired with magnetic disturbances; compasses spin wildly nearby. Metal objects attract arcs, so loose equipment can be weaponized by the anomaly itself.
Trade/Use: Ecologists (GOC) prize Electra samples; small electrodes or residual charges can be harvested for study. Only the experienced risk extracting them, as containment is difficult. Stalkers rarely trade directly with these; the hazard is too great for casual handling.
Advice: Maintain distance, keep gear grounded if possible, and don’t step into areas where arcs are already dancing. Do not touch, do not move metal carelessly, and remember: electricity does not forgive mistakes. Respect it, or it will write its own lesson in burns and broken bones.
— The Guide


Moonlight

item.title: Fruit Punch
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

Small, low to the ground, and deceptive. The Fruit Punch anomaly is easy to overlook if you’re not paying attention. It looks almost playful: a shallow pool of liquid, green in color, sometimes bubbling faintly, sometimes still. The smell is strange; sweet at first, like overripe fruit, with an undertone that makes your stomach turn.
Behaviour: entirely unpredictable. Step too close, and it lashes out; not with fire or electricity, but with a sudden, corrosive splash that burns skin and eats through cloth. Not lethal at first contact for hardened stalkers, but lingering exposure is dangerous; nausea, burns, and sometimes worse have been reported.
Detection: Best approached with caution. Leaves a faint heat signature detectable by thermals; sometimes small ripples or shifting reflections betray its presence. Radiation levels are low but erratic. The Ecologists (GOC) speculate it may be a chemical-anomalous hybrid; a reaction between Zone mutagens and stagnant water, though no one really knows.
Trade/Use: Some stalkers harvest small samples for Ecologists (GOC); a vial of Fruit Punch can fetch modest coin if intact. Handle carefully, or you’ll burn your hands and your reputation.
Advice: Do not taste, do not touch without gloves, and approach with eyes wide. It may look harmless; or even tempting, but the Zone has no generosity in things that look sweet.
— The Guide

item.title: Springboard
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

The Springboard anomaly is one of the trickier ones to predict. At first glance, it looks like nothing more than an ordinary patch of ground; dirt, moss, maybe a shallow depression. Step on it without caution, though, and it launches you with force, as if the earth itself is hurling you into the air.
Behaviour: Erratic. Some Springboards flicker, activating only when weight is applied in a certain spot. Others reset slowly, giving you a moment of safety, then snapping again if you linger. The trajectory is inconsistent, sometimes high and short, sometimes long and low. Landing is the real danger: hard impacts, broken bones, or inadvertent collisions with nearby anomalies are common.
Detection: Subtle signs; slightly discoloured earth, compressed soil, or faint vibrations in the ground. Thermals are useless. Only caution, careful probing, and slow movement reveal it before it strikes.
Trade/Use: Of little direct value. Ecologists (GOC) might harvest small soil or residue samples to study the anomaly’s mechanics, but the real interest is theoretical. Stalkers generally avoid carrying Springboard samples; a misstep can kill in an instant.
Advice: Probe the ground before you step, travel light, and wear protective gear if possible. Treat every odd patch of earth with suspicion; the Zone is never idle, and even the ground can turn against you.
— The Guide


Medusa

item.title: Battery
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

The “Battery” is a common artefact formed near Electra anomalies. Roughly oval, blue, smooth to the touch, and faintly warm, it gives off a subtle hum if you hold it to your ear; like a live wire under the skin.
Positives - Unknown, said to recharge electrical items
Drawbacks: Gives off a minor constant dosage of radiation.
Trade Value: Moderate. Stalkers prize it for long treks and supply hauls. Ecologists (GOC) pay steadily for clean samples, seeing it as a bridge between organic energy and electromagnetic phenomena. Freedom (GOC) makes good use of them for scouts. Duty (GOC) tends to seize them, citing “public safety.”
Advice: Useful in the field, but don’t grow dependent. Rotate artefacts often, and never carry a Battery too close to your chest for long. The Zone has a way of turning every gift into a poison.
— The Guide

item.title: Dog Heart
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

📓 FIELD SAMPLE – “Blind Dog Heart” (Removed)
Condition: Freshly excised, minimal degradation
Sample ID: BD-HRT-09
Date: 27.08.25
Source: Adult specimen, female, killed near Rostok (GOC) outskirts
Collected a heart from a Blind Dog this morning. Procedure: field removal, standard blade work, gloves on. No anomalies present in carcass at time of dissection. Organ was larger than baseline canid size — roughly 1.5× normal mass. Texture spongier than expected. Dark coloration, almost bruised, but no external damage.
Notable observations:

Heart showed signs of additional vascularization; tangled vessels around the aortic arch. Possibly adaptive, possibly mutation-driven.

Traces of luminescence under UV lamp (portable Ecologist issue). Faint, but present. Indicates residual radiation saturation.

Still gave faint electrical twitch for several minutes post-removal. This is not normal physiology.

Speculative notes: Ecologists suggest mutant organs hold traces of Zone energy even after death. This one may be of value for study, though carrying it unshielded is unwise. Dosimeter rose slightly when stored close to my person. Recommend lead-lined containment for long-term transport if prudent, otherwise, low to background radiation.
Practical use: Traders sometimes buy organs like this for backroom markets. Some claim they’re used in tinctures, talismans, or underground medicine. I wouldn’t trust any of it in my bloodstream, but superstition keeps the demand alive.
Advice for stalkers: if you’re going to carve organs, do it clean and fast. Keep tools separate from eating gear. And remember; Zone flesh rots differently. Best not to linger when you’re elbow-deep in something that shouldn’t exist.
— The Guide

item.title: Dog Liver
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

📓 FIELD SAMPLE – “Blind Dog Liver” (Removed)
Condition: Freshly excised, minimal degradation
Sample ID: BD-LVR-09
Date: 27.08.25
Source: Adult specimen, female, killed near Rostok (GOC) outskirts
Pulled the liver from a medium-sized Blind Dog this afternoon. Removed in the field, two cuts, careful work — kept gloves on, wrapped in waxed cloth, sealed in a metal canister. Took the long way back to camp; dosimeter ticked a touch higher than baseline while I carried it.
Macroscopic description:

Size: larger than a normal canine liver, estimate ~1.3× expected mass for a dog this size.

Colour: mottled dark-brown with streaks of near-black; occasional pale splotches like old scarring. Surface slightly glossy, not the dry, leathery texture you get from long-dead meat.

Consistency: firmer than normal, with dense lobulation. When sliced, tissue felt rubbery rather than crumbly. Bile ducts present and swollen. No obvious ruptures.

Notable observations:

Under a UV lamp the tissue fluoresced faintly along venous channels; a slow, dull shimmer, not a bright glow. Ecologist kit indicates radiation residue still present.

Vascular pattern was abnormal: extra branching near the portal region and tangles of microvessels not typical of normal anatomy. Could be adaptive; increased circulation to compensate for whatever replaced their sight.

Tissue reacted to a cold saline rinse with twitching along cut edges for a short time. Electrical response, faint but noticeable. Suggests lingering bioelectrical activity even after death.

Preliminary risks:

Elevated residual radiation reading when unshielded. Not extreme, but measurable. Store in lead-lined container; keep away from food and sleeping quarters.

Possible biohazard: no spores visible, but mutant organs can carry unknown pathogens. Sterilise tools and burn non-essential waste.

Potential uses / trade value:

Ecologists will want a sample for histology and to map vascular anomalies; strike a bargain if you can.

Black-market buyers pay for fresh mutant organs; liver fetches moderate coin if intact. Traders value the liver for tinctures and “research” buyers, though I’d not drink whatever they brew.

Practically: not fit for consumption. No trader worth the name will risk eating it, and with good reason.

Field recommendation:

Submit a tissue slice to the Ecologist contact at the next meeting. Preserve remainder in lead-lined container, refrigerated if possible.

Tag the carcass location on the map and leave clear warnings; packs of Blind Dogs return to the same kill sites.

Remind rookies: if you’re extracting organs, move fast, burn what you don’t carry, and never sleep with the canister under your blanket.

Small things teach big lessons out here. The liver tells a tale of strain; of extra work, extra blood, life forced into a new shape by the Zone. Keep your hands clean and your feet moving.
— The Guide

item.title: Dog Tail
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.

📓 FIELD SAMPLE – “Blind Dog Tail” (Removed)
Condition: Freshly excised, minimal degradation
Sample ID: BD-TIL-09
Date: 27.08.25
Source: Adult specimen, female, killed near Rostok (GOC) outskirts
Cut the tail off a medium Blind Dog this morning — field removal, clean slice at the caudal vertebrae, cauterised the wound to slow bleed. Wrapped in oiled cloth and sealed in a metal tin. Carried it inboard for testing; dosimeter ticked up when it was against my hip, nothing dramatic but worth noting.
Macroscopic description:

Length: approx. 35–45 cm on this specimen (longer on larger animals).

Appearance: patchy fur, sections of exposed, toughened skin. End shows hardened keratinous growths in some specimens; looks like a natural club forming.

Consistency: core tissue dense and fibrous; vertebrae show ossified protrusions in places. Tail moves with surprising force when fresh; strong musculature for balance and as a weapon.

Notable observations:

When flexed, faint electrical spasm in musculature observed; not voluntary, but persistent for a short while after removal.

Surface parasites visible in one area; burn and disinfect any unused tissue.

Risks & Handling:

Slight but measurable radiation when unshielded. Store in lead-lined or metal container. Do not sleep with it in your tent.

Possible biological contamination; sterilise tools, burn scraps, and keep separate from food and water. If you touch it, wash and disinfect before treating wounds or eating.

Practical uses / Market:

Trophies & trinkets: claws and tail tips fetch decent coin with collectors and armour-smiths who mount them on gear.

Alchemical / black-market: glandular nodules and tail tissue are sought after by underground apothecaries and some traders for experimental tinctures and reagents.

Research: Ecologists value a sample for morphology studies; particularly the ossified protrusions and glandular structures.

Trade note — Duty (GOC):

Duty (GOC) outposts around Rostok (GOC) and the service road will buy mutant parts, including tails. They pay reliably and better than the street vendors, especially for intact samples and glandular sections.

Trade with Duty comes with paperwork and questions; they like to know where you found it. Expect to be logged. Good coin, but you’re on their record after that. Trade cleanly, take the receipt, and don’t be surprised if they ask you to bring more.
Trade note — Sidorovich (GOC):

Dont go anywhere near unless you're desperate. Old man scams you right out.
Field recommendation:

If you’re harvesting, remove only what you can carry and keep the tail whole if possible; intact samples fetch a higher price. Slice a small tissue plug for the Ecologist and keep the rest sealed.

Burn what you won’t sell or hand over to traders; rotting mutant parts attract packs.

Remember: Duty (GOC) buys, but they also keep tabs. Decide if the coin is worth being noticed.

Small things in the Zone pay big in trouble and coin. Harvest smart, transport safer, and know who you’re selling to.
— The Guide

item.title: Blind Dogs
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.


Category: Tier I Threat
Disposition: Pack-hunting, aggressive when provoked
Common Locations: Open fields, ruined villages, roadside clearings
The Blind Dog is a reminder that the Zone doesn’t need claws the size of knives to be dangerous. They look like half-starved strays at first glance — ribs showing, fur patchy, eyes clouded white or gone altogether. Don’t be fooled. Their lack of sight doesn’t slow them. If anything, it’s made them better hunters. They track by smell, by sound, and by whatever sense the Zone carved into their brains in place of vision.
One dog alone isn’t much of a threat — though it’ll still try to bite chunks out of you. The danger comes from the pack. They circle, flank, and drive their prey straight into ambush. I’ve watched rookies laugh at the first one that comes growling, only to be screaming seconds later when five more tear in from the sides.
Behavior: opportunistic. They’ll scavenge corpses as quick as they’ll run down a living man. Loud noises draw them — gunfire especially. Packs often shadow stalkers for kilometers, waiting until fatigue sets in or ammunition runs low.
I’ve noticed something odd over the years: they don’t always attack. Sometimes they just linger at the edge of campfires, keeping their distance, heads tilted, listening. Like they’re waiting for something. Makes my skin crawl.
Harvestable components: pelts (poor quality, but traders sometimes take them), meat (severely irradiated — do not consume), and occasionally teeth used for charms.
Advice? Don’t underestimate them. If you hear growling in the grass, assume the pack is already in motion. Best defense is firepower and awareness. Or, if you’re smart, don’t be there when they come sniffing.
— The Guide

item.title: Bloodsucker
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.

📓 MUTANT DOSSIER – “Bloodsucker”
Category: Tier III Threat
Disposition: Highly aggressive, ambush predator
Common Locations: Marshes, abandoned structures, deep forests, subterranean tunnels
If the Zone has nightmares, the Bloodsucker is the shape they take. Tall, gaunt, wrapped in corded muscle under a leathery hide. The head alone is enough to freeze a man’s heart — mandibles splitting wide, tendrils thrashing, a mouth built for one thing: draining the life out of whatever it catches.
They hunt alone. Silent, patient. Their gift is worse than their claws — an ability to fade from sight, bending light around their bodies until they’re little more than a shimmer in the air. You won’t hear them. You won’t smell them. You’ll only know when they’re on top of you, mandibles locked around your throat.
Behavior: apex predator. They toy with prey, sometimes dragging bodies back to lairs. I’ve seen nests littered with half-eaten corpses — stalkers, loners, even mutants. Some whisper they’re intelligent, that they plan their hunts. I can’t prove that, but I’ve looked into one’s eyes, and I didn’t see animal hunger. I saw calculation.
Defenses: difficult to detect when cloaked. Thermal optics help, as does throwing bolts or debris to catch movement. They’re vulnerable to sustained fire, though many stalkers don’t get the chance to reload once one’s in striking distance. Shotguns work best up close.
Harvestable components: tendril clusters (valuable to Ecologists and certain black-market traders). Hide sometimes traded for study. Meat is inedible — rancid with radiation.
Advice? If you suspect a Bloodsucker is near, assume you’re already being hunted. Keep your back to a wall, your weapon loaded, and your nerves steady. Don’t panic when the air shimmers. If you panic, you’re already dead.
— The Guide

item.title: Flesh
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.


Category: Tier I Threat
Disposition: Neutral-aggressive
Common Locations: Open fields, near abandoned farms, shallow woodlands
One of the more grotesquely common mutants in the Zone. The Flesh resembles a hairless, overgrown pig; though calling it a pig does a disservice to bacon. Its hide is thick, leathery, and often torn, stretched unnaturally around warped bone and muscle that shouldn’t exist in nature. Eyes are human-like, unsettlingly so. There's thought behind them. Not much, but enough to watch. Enough to wait.
It moves in herds, usually slow, sometimes grazing like livestock; until it smells blood or hears a gunshot. Then it charges. Quick for its bulk. Powerful jaws. I’ve seen one rip a man's thigh clean open before he could reload.
Ecologists speculate it was once livestock exposed to radiation or mutated from swine stock scavenging the Zone’s dead zones. Some stalkers think they're failed experiments. Me? I think they're proof the Zone doesn't forget what we fed it. It just spits it back, wrong.
Harvestable components: Eye, sell to Duty (GOC)
Don’t provoke unless you’re hungry or bored. Better to let them pass and stay unseen. There are worse things out there that come running when a Flesh starts squealing.
Sneaky little fuckers. Almost silent. Keep head on swivel.
— The Guide

item.title: Izlom
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.


Category: Tier II Threat
Disposition: Unpredictable
Common Locations: Abandoned industrial zones, ruins, deep woodland clearings
The Izlom is something that shouldn’t be; a thing that walks like a man but is anything but. You’ll know one when you see it: long, lurching limbs, one arm dragging like it's dead weight, the other overdeveloped and jittering. Legs twisted but functional, gait somewhere between a drunk and a predator. The face is the worst part; almost human, if you squint, and it never stops grinning.
Most stalkers write them off as madmen in the late stages of mutation; maybe ex-military or researchers caught in radiation Pockets too long. Whatever they were, that person is long gone. What’s left is a creature that mimics humanity just enough to make your skin crawl.
Behaviour varies. I’ve seen them mumble and stagger away like drunk philosophers. I’ve also seen them fly into a rage at the snap of a twig and beat a man into mulch with one arm. They’re strong. Disturbingly strong. And fast, despite the limp.
Some factions say they can talk; not just groan or howl, but actually speak. I’ve only heard them mutter gibberish. One repeated "Don't go down" over and over again while eating a dog carcass. Didn’t stay to ask what he meant.
Harvestable components: not much. Maybe tissue samples for the Eggheads. Hands mostly sell with Duty (GOC). They’re more valuable dead and documented than anything else. I don’t trust the meat, even to sell. Something about them feels... tainted, deeper than radiation or rot.
Avoid if possible. Kill if necessary. And if it starts talking; don't listen.
— The Guide

item.title: Wild Cat
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox “Img” is not created yet. Click to create.

📓 MUTANT DOSSIER – “Wild Cat”
Category: Tier I Threat
Disposition: Predatory
Common Locations: Forest edges, abandoned settlements, tall grass and scrub zones
The Zone doesn’t lack for predators, but the Wild Cat is one of the purest hunters out here. Imagine a lynx or mountain lion dragged through the Aether, stretched and hardened into something leaner, hungrier, and meaner. They move low, almost silent, muscles like coiled wire under patchy fur. Their eyes shine even when there’s no light to catch — green, burning, too aware.
Unlike Flesh or Dogs, Cats hunt alone or in pairs. They don’t waste energy. They stalk. Wait. Watch. And when they decide to move, it’s already too late. I’ve seen one leap clean from the roof of a farmhouse onto a stalker, knocking him flat before he even drew his pistol. The claws do the work — long, curved, and strong enough to carve through thick canvas or even the lighter plates of a stalker vest.
They don’t roar or howl. The Zone made them quiet. The only warning is the silence before they strike — birds scatter, dogs shut up, even the wind seems to die. That’s when you should get your rifle ready.
Ecologists think they’re mutated big cats, maybe from zoo stock or circus animals left behind when everything went to hell. Some stalkers whisper that they were bred deliberately, experiments in predation. I don’t much care. Out here, the “why” doesn’t matter. Only the “how fast can you kill it before it kills you.”
Harvestable components: pelts (fetch good prices with traders), claws (sometimes taken as trophies or sold for trinkets). Meat is foul, tainted with radiation. Don’t bother.
Advice? Never turn your back in the bush. If you feel eyes on you, you’re probably right. And if you catch a glimpse of fur vanishing between trees — you might already be in its sights.
— The Guide

item.title: Wish Granter
item.description:
#GOC #Research

#GOC #Research
Infobox

Every campfire in the Zone has its ghost stories, and at the heart of them all lies the same whispered tale; the “Wish Granter.” They say, if a man reaches the very centre of the Zone, past the Red Forest, past the brain-burners and the Monolith (GOC), he’ll find it waiting.
Some describe it as a machine, others as a crystal, some as a voice that lives in the dark. All agree on one thing: it grants wishes. Riches, salvation, healing, a second chance. Every stalker has heard a version, and every stalker claims to know someone who knew a man who made it there. None can prove it.
The Monolith (GOC) themselves seem tied to it. Their sermons speak of a holy light, of a gift from the Zone itself. Could the “Wish Granter” be their god? Or just a mirage that keeps them fighting like madmen?
I have heard other versions; darker ones. That it twists what you ask for. That it gives nothing but illusions, or worse, curses. One old drunk in Rostok (GOC) swore his brother reached it and asked for immortality. The man vanished. The next week, dogs dragged his half-burned corpse back to the camp.
Is it real? A lure? An anomaly too complex to understand? I cannot say. But I will say this: anything the Zone “offers” comes with a price. If you go chasing wishes, be prepared to pay more than your life.
— The Guide

item.title: Wild Territory (GOC)
item.description:
#GOC

#GOC
#📓 TERRITORY NOTES – West of Rostok
The land west of Rostok (GOC) is no place for the careless. Open fields give way to broken forests, and the remnants of old industrial zones — rusted warehouses, toppled cranes, and abandoned rail lines — dot the landscape like the bones of some long-dead beast. The Zone here feels older, wilder, less tamed than the roads and villages nearer to Rostok (GOC) itself.
Terrain: uneven and unpredictable. Pockets of swamp, exposed rubble, and sudden pits hide beneath grass and brush. Anomalies pepper the area, some small and easily avoided, others enough to kill a man before he sees them. Streams and irrigation ditches twist through the land, carrying chemical runoff, radiation, and the occasional mutated fish or amphibian.
Fauna: packs of Blind Dogs patrol the edges of ruins; wild cats stalk the fields, usually at night. Flesh mutants are less common but occasionally move through the forested patches. Tracks show signs of Izlom's ranging through the structures and streets. Bloodsuckers lurk in the abandoned structures, hunting anything foolish enough to enter. Zombie (GOC)'s prowl where they unluckily got caught up in an Emission.
Hazards:

Medium Level radiation zones

Residual anomalies — Flame, Burner, and Springboard are common along derelict roads.

Rogue stalkers and bandits operate from hidden camps, preying on unwary travellers.

Survival Advice:

Travel light but carry enough rations; there are no safe supply caches for long stretches.

Keep to high ground where possible — packs and anomalies favour lower areas.

Avoid the industrial ruins at night unless you’re armed and prepared; shadows are full of predators and things you don’t want to meet.

Map your route carefully; landmarks shift, and the Zone doesn’t forgive wandering.

Notes: This territory is dangerous but also rich in loot if one knows where to look. Artifacts often collect near small anomaly clusters hidden among rubble. The risk is high, but the reward; rare artifacts, equipment, and valuable low to medium end mutant parts can make it worth the gamble for those who understand the land.
— The Guide

item.title: 20240719 - Rostok Route
item.description:
#LITZ #Journal #ExpeditionLog

#LITZ #Journal #ExpeditionLog


Proceeded to Rostok with Walter Shenoski





Walter Shenoski and I were going to head to Rostok (LITZ), he had some stuff to sell and I needed to learn the route. We were joined by another random Loner (LITZ) we found at Rookie Village (GOC). He was a little strange and monotone and at the time we didn't realise what would happen next. Turns out the guy was Monolith (LITZ), they were after me. Turns out I am Most Wanted.
We made our way to North Farm to stop off during the dark. While there, the random Loner turned on us. Attacked and tried to rob us. I surrendered but Walter Shenoski ended up killing the guy, but his gear got wrecked. We laughed it off and headed further North.

WARNING Radiation / Pseudodog
We headed north through the Military checkpoint and on the road north, we were attacked by a Pseuddog. We had to run due to being close to the Bandits (LITZ).

We went east and circled around to avoid going North past the Bandits (LITZ) HQ in the Train Yard. I went loud by accident after we were attacked by BlindDogs. We had to run as fast as we could.

We stopped off at Flea Market (LITZ), there were two Stash's, one in the basement and one in the roof.

We headed North, attacked by a few dogs. It was close to an Emission and we made a run for it. Hiding in the bunker just outside the entrance.

Unfortunatly that was where it all went bad. We headed inside and were immedietly jumped by a pair of Monolith (LITZ). Walter Shenoski was killed for chatting shit and I was let go. The guy at the start had been in contact with his brothers.
I went inside and met a Duty (LITZ) guy. He had been jumped by them too, managing to kill the one he'd seen.

I made a return run for Cordon (LITZ), only getting into trouble with a dog but otherwise, made it back nice and safe.


Monolith tried to assassinate me. Found out later I was a HVT on their list, because I helped people.

item.title: Building
item.description:
Double Doors

Fence

2x Wooden logs
18x Planks (5x Wooden logs)
36x Nails

Splitting Axe

Shovel

Pickaxe

Hammer

Hatchet

Hacksaw

Handsaw
Note: You will need one or the other of the Shovel and Pickaxe. The handsaw and hacksaw can be used to saw or make planks.
Crafting
The basic Kits:
a wooden pallet + 5 Planks:

Table Kit
Cabinet Kit
Bed Kit
Sofa Kit
Box Kit
Special Kit
Furniture Kits have multiple "pallet slots". Depending on how many pallets you put into your kit, you can place different Things.
Table Kit
1 Pallet = Small table. --- 2 Pallets = Medium table. --- 3 Pallets = Large table.
Bed Kit
3 Pallets = Small bed. --- 4 Pallets = Large bed.
Sofa Kit
!! BUGGED !!
2 Pallets = Small sofa. --- 3 Pallets = Medium sofa. --- 4 Pallets = Large sofa.
Cabinet Kit
1 Pallet = Pallet Shelf (for up to 3 wooden crates). 2 Pallets = Gun Cabinet. --- 3 Pallets = Medium Cabinet. --- 4 Pallets = Large Cabinet.
Old Wooden Crate (required for the Medium Cabinet):
10 Planks + 16 Nails
Special Kit
2 Pallets = Trashcan. --- 3 Pallets = Workbench. --- 5 Pallets = Greenhouse. --- 4 Fabric = Log Storage Place
Box Kit
Instead of slots for pallets, you need to put pallet frames in this Kit (max 4). The more frames you use, the bigger is the box you can place.
A Frame requires 4 Planks and 24 Nails
Stove Kit
combine a empty barrel + a Hacksaw.
Fill the material Slot of the Kit (10 Metal Sheets) to place the Stove.
Rain Collector Kit
combine a wooden pallet + 4 Metal Sheets.
Fill the material Slot of the Kit (4 fabric) to place the Rain Collector.
CRAFTING ON THE WORKBENCH:
Old Fridge
10 metal plates, 1 metal wire and an electronic repair kit.
Tool in your Hands: Screwdriver
Currently the fridge doesn't need to be powered (may change in future updates) but will increase the hold time of food. By default food will hold 3 times longer - but this may vary because it is configurable.
Repairbench
10 metal plates, 10 wooden planks and 30 nails.
Tool in your Hands: Screwdriver
The repairbench acts as a repair booster. Add repairkits to the repairbench and take the damaged item in your hands to use the bench.
The repairbench repairs faster, can repair to pristine and your attached repairkits will last longer.
Small Spotlight
1 metal plate, 1 metal wire and 25% of an electronic repair kit.
Tool in your Hand: Screwdriver
This small Spotlight can be powered by a 9V Battery and can be placed on the Ground.
It also works in artificial darkness areas like bunkers.
Desk Lamp
1 metal plate, 3 wooden planks and 25% of an electronic repair kit.
Tool in your Hand: Screwdriver
You can change the position of the lamps head. The desk lamp will also work in artificial darkness.
Floor Lamp
a metal pipe, 1 metal wire, 2 wooden planks and 25% of an electronic repair kit
Tool in your Hand: Screwdriver
The floor lamp needs to be powered from external sources - like a generator or a truck battery with wire.
It's an all-around light and therefore is disabled to work in artificial darkness for performance reasons.
Solar Panel
10 metal plates, 1 metal wire and an electronic repair kit.
Tool in your Hand: Blowtorch
The solarpanel requires a truck battery to work. It needs to be turned on to charge the battery at daytime.
Firewood Storage Place
4 metal plates
Tool in your Hand: Blowtorch
A small storage place for firewood, wooden sticks and other stuff to make a cozy fire.
Coffee Machine
10 metal plates, 1 metal wire and an electronic repair kit.
Tool in your Hand: Blowtorch
A cool retro coffee machine to make you a cup of coffee. Add a bag of coffee beans and fill the machine with water. Doesn't need to be powered (may change in future updates)
